title: 111_hr5938
content: The "Children First Act of 2010" excludes child care from TANF assistance and increases funding for child care. The Children First Act of 2010 excludes child care from TANF assistance and increases funding for child care significantly from 2011 to 2015. Additionally, there is a provision regarding the applicability of state or local health and safety standards to other TANF child care spending. Section 402(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to require certification of procedures to ensure child care providers comply with state or local health and safety standards. This is in relation to the availability of child care for parents required to work. SEC. 5. Availability of child care for parents required to work is expanded to include individuals with custody, and the age limit for child care is increased to 13. SEC. 6. Reporting rules from the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 now apply to TANF funds used for child care. Section 411(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include reporting rules from the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 for funds expended on child care. This applies regardless of whether the funds are transferred to the Block Grant Act or not. The Social Security Act is amended to include reporting rules for funds spent on child care, regardless of transfer to the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. The effective date for the amendments to the Social Security Act regarding reporting rules for child care funds is specified in Section 7. The amendments made by this Act will take effect on October 1, 2010, for payments under part A of title IV of the Social Security Act. Section 6 amendments will be effective on October 1, 2011. States requiring legislation to meet the new requirements will have a delay in compliance. States with 2-year legislative sessions must comply with new requirements by the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter after the State legislature's regular session. Each year of the session is considered a separate regular session.
